OptimalBinningWoE 0.1.5.9005

Generates a Comprehensive Gains Table from Optimal Binning Results

OptimalBinningGainsTable.Rd

This function takes the result of the optimal binning process and generates a detailed gains table. The table includes various metrics to assess the performance and characteristics of each bin.

Usage

OptimalBinningGainsTable(binning_result)

Arguments

binning_result

A list containing the binning results, which must include a data frame with the following columns: "bin", "count", "count_pos", "count_neg", and "woe".

Value

A data frame containing the following columns for each bin:

  • bin: The bin labels.

  • count: Total count of observations in the bin.

  • pos: Count of positive events in the bin.

  • neg: Count of negative events in the bin.

  • woe: Weight of Evidence (WoE) for the bin.

  • iv: Information Value (IV) contribution for the bin.

  • total_iv: Total Information Value (IV) across all bins.

  • cum_pos: Cumulative count of positive events up to the current bin.

  • cum_neg: Cumulative count of negative events up to the current bin.

  • pos_rate: Rate of positive events within the bin.

  • neg_rate: Rate of negative events within the bin.

  • pos_perc: Percentage of positive events relative to the total positive events.

  • neg_perc: Percentage of negative events relative to the total negative events.

  • count_perc: Percentage of total observations in the bin.

  • cum_count_perc: Cumulative percentage of observations up to the current bin.

  • cum_pos_perc: Cumulative percentage of positive events up to the current bin.

  • cum_neg_perc: Cumulative percentage of negative events up to the current bin.

  • cum_pos_perc_total: Cumulative percentage of positive events relative to total observations.

  • cum_neg_perc_total: Cumulative percentage of negative events relative to total observations.

  • odds_pos: Odds of positive events in the bin.

  • odds_ratio: Odds ratio of positive events compared to the total population.

  • lift: Lift of the bin, calculated as the ratio of the positive rate in the bin to the overall positive rate.

  • ks: Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic, measuring the difference between cumulative positive and negative percentages.

  • gini_contribution: Contribution to the Gini coefficient for each bin.

  • precision: Precision of the bin.

  • recall: Recall up to the current bin.

  • f1_score: F1 score for the bin.

  • log_likelihood: Log-likelihood of the bin.

  • kl_divergence: Kullback-Leibler divergence for the bin.

  • js_divergence: Jensen-Shannon divergence for the bin.

Details

The function calculates various metrics for each bin:

  • Weight of Evidence (WoE): $$WoE_i = \ln\left(\frac{P(X_i|Y=1)}{P(X_i|Y=0)}\right)$$

  • Information Value (IV): $$IV_i = (P(X_i|Y=1) - P(X_i|Y=0)) \times WoE_i$$

  • Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) statistic: $$KS_i = |F_1(i) - F_0(i)|$$ where \(F_1(i)\) and \(F_0(i)\) are the cumulative distribution functions for positive and negative classes.

  • Odds Ratio: $$OR_i = \frac{P(Y=1|X_i) / P(Y=0|X_i)}{P(Y=1) / P(Y=0)}$$

  • Lift: $$Lift_i = \frac{P(Y=1|X_i)}{P(Y=1)}$$

  • Gini Contribution: $$Gini_i = P(X_i|Y=1) \times F_0(i) - P(X_i|Y=0) \times F_1(i)$$

  • Precision: $$Precision_i = \frac{TP_i}{TP_i + FP_i}$$

  • Recall: $$Recall_i = \frac{\sum_{j=1}^i TP_j}{\sum_{j=1}^n TP_j}$$

  • F1 Score: $$F1_i = 2 \times \frac{Precision_i \times Recall_i}{Precision_i + Recall_i}$$

  • Log-likelihood: $$LL_i = n_{1i} \ln(p_i) + n_{0i} \ln(1-p_i)$$ where \(n_{1i}\) and \(n_{0i}\) are the counts of positive and negative cases in bin i, and \(p_i\) is the proportion of positive cases in bin i.

  • Kullback-Leibler (KL) Divergence: $$KL_i = p_i \ln\left(\frac{p_i}{p}\right) + (1-p_i) \ln\left(\frac{1-p_i}{1-p}\right)$$ where \(p_i\) is the proportion of positive cases in bin i and \(p\) is the overall proportion of positive cases.

  • Jensen-Shannon (JS) Divergence: $$JS_i = \frac{1}{2}KL(p_i || m) + \frac{1}{2}KL(q_i || m)$$ where \(m = \frac{1}{2}(p_i + p)\), \(p_i\) is the proportion of positive cases in bin i, and \(p\) is the overall proportion of positive cases.

References

  • Siddiqi, N. (2006). Credit Risk Scorecards: Developing and Implementing Intelligent Credit Scoring. John Wiley & Sons.

  • Hand, D. J., & Till, R. J. (2001). A Simple Generalisation of the Area Under the ROC Curve for Multiple Class Classification Problems. Machine Learning, 45(2), 171-186.

  • Kullback, S., & Leibler, R. A. (1951). On Information and Sufficiency. The Annals of Mathematical Statistics, 22(1), 79-86.

  • Lin, J. (1991). Divergence measures based on the Shannon entropy. IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, 37(1), 145-151.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
binning_result <- OptimalBinning(target, feature)
gains_table <- OptimalBinningGainsTable(binning_result)
print(gains_table)
} # }
